abstract: Fly through this puzzle by Dan Schoenholz.

lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — One of the issues that constructors have with creating a quip or quote puzzle is that not all quips or quotes break into “chunks” that scan well. For solvers, working a puzzle that has a quip or quote that is broken up into weird or partial phrases is not as much fun as one that reads beautifully. For an editor like Will Shortz, who has seen his share of quip or quote puzzles, it can become tiresome to run this type of theme on a regular basis, because repeating themes is boring and because they probably need a lot of work before they’re ready for prime time.

headline.main: Become Hardened

lead_paragraph: It’s not a big surprise that Marissa Mayer has failed to resurrect Yahoo. When the celebrated Google executive took over the web’s most iconic basket case in 2012, the odds were stacked against her. Turning around any company is difficult; turning around a tech company is nearly unheard-of. There’s just one example everyone can think of — Apple — but that effort took nearly a decade to show results, and anyway, if your requirement for success is to be like Steve Jobs, good luck to you.

lead_paragraph: STOCKHOLM — Parishioners text tithes to their churches. Homeless street vendors carry mobile credit-card readers. Even the Abba Museum, despite being a shrine to the 1970s pop group that wrote “Money, Money, Money,” considers cash so last-century that it does not accept bills and coins.

headline.main: In Sweden, a Cash-Free Future Nears
headline.print_headline: Where Even Banks Don’t Accept Cash Anymore

abstract: Links to the 51 Numberplay puzzles of 2015.

lead_paragraph: Here they are — the Numberplay puzzles of 2015, including this week’s Gift Exchange by the Dutch mathematician Henk Tijms. Nearly all these puzzles are original, and many were unveiled for the first time here on Numberplay. All works of art. Thank you to everyone who submitted a puzzle this year, and thank you as well to everyone who participated in the puzzle-solving discussion (where the real fun is, in case you haven’t tried it!) or shared these puzzles with friends. Math is a highly social activity, and puzzles are a great excuse for fun conversation.
